Garden Farm, on the Osborne Turnpike, Five miles from Richmond, containing about Fifty-three at Res of land, for Sale at Auction.--At the request of Mr. Martin Baker, I will sell, on Tuesday, the 10th instant, on the premises at 1 o'clock P. M., the Farm, on the Osborne turnpike, at present occupied by Mr. Baker.
The farm contains about fifty-three acres of land.
About one-third of the land is in low grounds.
Nearly all the land is cleared and ready for cultivation.
The farm is well watered; The buildings consist of a story framed house, with about six rooms, with a kitchen and corn-house, &c. It is located in a desirable neighborhood, and is very healthy, and on one of the best reads leading to Richmond,--Persons wishing to secure a desirable small farm would do well to attend the sale.
Terms: Liberal, and made known on the day of sale.
Persons attending the sale will provide themselves with passes.

Schermerhorn, on the Mechanicville turnpike, about two miles from the city of Richmond, will be sold, on the premises, on Tuesday, the day of January, 1865, at 11 o'clock A. M., the Stock of Horses, Mules, &c., two Carriages and Harness and a one-Horse Carriage and Harness; and Plantation Utensils, consisting of Wheat Wheat Fan, Reaper, Carts, Plow, Brag, Harrows, &c. After the sale we will rent, for the present year, a small Farm of Sixty acres of Cleared land, well suited for a market garden; forty acres of which was highly manured the past year with a large quantity of manure.
The improvements are a small house, kitchen and table; with the privilege of the use of dead and waste wood for fuel from the wood land belonging to the farm.

div3.head: Administratrix's Sale of Personal property.
div3.p:
--As administratrix of the estate of the late Larking P. Ford.
I shall sell, at public auction at 11 o'clock, for cash, the Personal property of the deceased, consisting of the usual Household and Kitchen Furniture, including a very superior Pieces; one Cart, one Buggy and Harness, Saddle, &c., &c. The sale will take place at his late residence, on Grace, between Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth streets, on Tuesday, the 10th day of January, 1865.
div3.closer:
Caroline Ford.
Administratrix of Larking P. Ford, deceased. ja 9--2t*

div3.head: Sale of coal property.
div3.p: --Under an unexpired lease, having three years to run, will be sold, at the Clover Hill Pits, on Friday, the 20th instant, the Lease, Tools, Fixtures, &c., of the pits lately worked by Hall & Co., known as the Central Pits, in Chesterfield county.
This sale is made necessary by the death of Wilkins Hall, who was one of the partners, and is concurred in by his executor.
Terms: Cash.
div3.closer:
the Surviving Partners
of Hall & Co.
I concur in the above sale.
L. L. Lester,
Executor of W. Hall. deceased. ja 5--tds

div3.head: For Sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sold, at the residence of B. J. Johnson, in Chesterfield county, one and a half miles from Broad Rock, on Tuesday, the 10th instant, if fair, one fine Mule, two No. J Milch Cows, one only three years old (Haxall stock); two fine Calves and Hogs; one Wagon, with Harness for three mules; one No. 1 Cart, with iron axle, with Harness; two Buggies and Harness; one Rockaway.
Also, a large assortment of Farming Implements generally.
Under A Decree of the Hustings Court of the city of Richmond we will sell, on Wednesday, January 11th, at the auction house of Hill, Dickinson & Co., a likely Girl, about seventeen years of age.

div3.head: Executor's Notice.
div3.p:
--All persons having claims against John Jacob, Sr., deceased, will present them immediately to the undersigned for settlement.
If not presented by the 7th of January next, this notice will be plead against all such claims.

For Sale, a No. 1 Sewing-Machine (Sloat's patent), in good order; also, some.
Needles for it. Inquire on Leigh street, between Adams and Foushes, at the residence of William.
Partington.

div3.head:

Confederate States of America,
Richmond, August 8, 1864.
div3.p:
Certificates of Indebtedness Bearing Six Per Cent. Per interest and free from Taxation. --the fourteenth section of the act to reduce the currency, approved February 17, 1864, the Secretary the Treasury is authorized to issue the short certificates, payable two years after the ratification of treaty of peace with the United States.
They are not be sold, but are only to be issued to such of the Government as are willing to same in payment of their demands.
They must be given at par, though free from.
Taxation.

Navy Department,
Office Special service,
Richmond, Va., September 19, 1864.
div3.p: Notice,--From and after Monday Next, the 26th instant, the Steamers Schrapnel, will leave the wharf at Rocketts the James River Squadron daily at 7 o'clock A. M. and 8 o'clock P. M., touching at all the principal landings on the river.

Richmond and Danville Railroad
Superintendent's Office.
January 2, 1865.
div3.p: Notice.--On and after Monday, January 2d, the through Passenger Train this read — leaving at 11 o'clock--will be the continued until further notice.

div3.head: For the Army.
div3.p:
--Francis Labarre, Manufacturer of Spurs and Bits.
Elastic Sturs; Gold, Silver Gilt Stars, for the staffs, Gilt Bars at captains and lieutenants; Badges, for the our neer and signed corps, &c.
Particular attention is given to work Maps order for Testimonials, such as Silvers Spurs, Gold Stars. &c., &c.,
Address Box 946, Richmond, Virginia.
